Once again, her dry lips were stained with blood. She blinked, taking in her surroundings. 

“So this is how you live, Sonia! I’ve never been in your room before.” 

She looked at Sonia, clearly in pain. 

“We’ve ruined you, Sonia. Polenka, Lida, Kolya, come here! Here they are, Sonia, take them all! I’m done! The party’s over.” (Cough!) “Just let me lie down and die in peace.” 

They gently laid her back on the pillow. 

“What about the priest? I don’t want him. You don’t have a rouble to spare. I have no sins. God can forgive me without that. He knows how much I’ve suffered… And if He doesn’t forgive me, whatever!” 

She slipped deeper into a restless delirium. Sometimes she shivered, her eyes darting around, recognizing everyone for a moment before drifting back into confusion. Her breathing was rough and labored, with a rattling sound in her throat. 

“I told him, your excellency,” she gasped after each word. “That Amalia Ludwigovna, ah! Lida, Kolya, hands on your hips, hurry up! Glide, glide! Step back! Tap your heels, be graceful!” 

“Du hast Diamanten und Perlen…” (You have diamonds and pearls...) 

“What’s next? That’s the song we should sing. 

“Du hast die schönsten Augen, Mädchen, was willst du mehr?” (You have the most beautiful eyes, girl, what more do you want?) 

“What a thought! What more do you want? What nonsense!”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Katerina Ivanovna, in a state of delirium and suffering, expresses her despair and resignation while entrusting her children to Sonia.
